comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Violet Romer (1886-1970), born in San Francisco as Violet Romer Shawhan.  She danced in London and New York, and was photographed by Edward Weston.  She turns up in several New York Times articles in the 1910s.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Given a similar number in the Bain scheme, this might have been taken/acquired in association with the same performance as www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3066025100/ that is described in NYT of Feb 12, 1913 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9402E3D71E3AE633A...

comment.author: 33013998@N03
comment._content: The emotion in Violet Romer's face shows that she is hurt. Her hand positions also indicate that she is telling someone to stay away because she is distressed. You can tell that she is a ballerina because of the way her feet are positioned and her beautiful arms.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Photographer's signature appears to be 'White, N.Y.'

comment.author: 32394499@N03
comment._content: Bonita fotografía,en donte se captó muy bien el elegante movimiento de baile.

comment.author: 105439146@N08
comment._content: It's Cousin Violet! Actually, she was my grandfather's first cousin. I met her when I was little. She was a self-taught modern dancer who was on Broadway. There are photos of her done by Edward Weston as well.
